bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to M. A. Roberts, March 13, 1929

div1.p: Carter points out that Roberts himself renewed her borrowing privileges for 1929. She also informs Roberts that she has kept no volumes out longer than the period afforded her by the Library of Congress.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to M. A. Roberts, March 13, 1929
div1.opener:
File: Book,
Miscl.
Library of Congress
DIVISION
/////
-----------------------------------
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
March 13, 1929.
Dear Mr. Roberts:
div1.p: Your letter, dated March 8th., has just reached me.

In regard to your attention having been directed to the
fact that I am supposed to have drawn books after the expiration,
without renewal, of the permit issued therefor in my favor for
1928: I would like to recall to your memory that not only was this
permit renewed for the year 1929, but that you,yourself, most
kindly put the matter through for me, while I waited in your office,
on December 31, 1928, and personally gave me the new card, for 1929,
before I left.

If there is any difficulty in checking this up, I will gladly
take you my renewed permit to draw books from the Library until December 31, 1929.
Also if you wish it, a carbon of my report to the Rockefeller Foun-
dation on the subject of having had my priveleges renewed at the
Library of Congress, which fixes the date. of renewal.
Re the list of books at the end of your letter: I would
state that I kept over no books from 1928 to 1929. Indeed, I went to
the Library of Congress, at considerable personal inconvenience (just
back from some very hard work in Baltimore) in order that I might turn
turn
-2-
in every book I had drawn out before the end of the year. This on
December 31, 1928, as I wished to do nothing which might complicate
your records for that year.

I have been, and am, too deeply appreciative of the unique and
generously-afforded facilities extended me for my work at the Library of
Congress not to endeavor, in every way, to conform to your procedure.
Indeed, to the best of my knowledge and belief, I have always done so,
and consider that to allow any part of your regulations to “escape” my
“notice” would, under such circumstances be well-nigh unpardonable.

I have been, and am, using the three books checked against
me for February, 1929. If, with my renewed permit for 1929, they are
still “overdue” I shall at once turn them in. If not, I should be
be very glad to e Las Casas and Oviedo y Yaldes a little longer.

I know you will be glad to hear that the work Father's book
is going well.. the revision and retyping of the last 3/5 of the bib-
liographic cards is about done and I'm hoping for a summons to Bal-
timore, for the resumption of the final editing, sometime this week.
After this I am looking forward to spending more time at the Library of
Congress--a much pleasanter place to work than one's apartment.
div1.closer:
With kindest regards, I remain
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura Armistead Carter, Mr. M. A. Roberts,
Superintendant of Reading Room,
Library of Congress,
Washington, D. C.
